segment.source: Get battery information
segment.target: Get battery information

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.Devices.Power
segment.target: Windows.Devices.Power

segment.source: DeviceInformation.FindAllAsync
segment.target: DeviceInformation.FindAllAsync

segment.source: Learn how to get detailed battery information using APIs in the Windows.Devices.Power namespace.
segment.target: Learn how to get detailed battery information using APIs in the Windows.Devices.Power namespace.

segment.source: A battery report (BatteryReport) describes the charge, capacity, and status of a battery or aggregate of batteries.
segment.target: A battery report (BatteryReport) describes the charge, capacity, and status of a battery or aggregate of batteries.

segment.source: This topic demonstrates how your app can get battery reports and be notified of changes.
segment.target: This topic demonstrates how your app can get battery reports and be notified of changes.

segment.source: Code examples are from the basic battery app that's listed at the end of this topic.
segment.target: Code examples are from the basic battery app that's listed at the end of this topic.

segment.source: Get aggregate battery report
segment.target: Get aggregate battery report

segment.source: Some devices have more than one battery and it's not always obvious how each battery contributes to the overall energy capacity of the device.
segment.target: Some devices have more than one battery and it's not always obvious how each battery contributes to the overall energy capacity of the device.

segment.source: This is where the AggregateBattery class comes in.
segment.target: This is where the AggregateBattery class comes in.

segment.source: The aggregate battery represents all battery controllers connected to the device and can provide a single overall BatteryReport object.
segment.target: The aggregate battery represents all battery controllers connected to the device and can provide a single overall BatteryReport object.

segment.source: Note A Battery class actually corresponds to a battery controller.
segment.target: Note A Battery class actually corresponds to a battery controller.

segment.source: Depending on the device, sometimes the controller is attached to the physical battery and sometimes it's attached to the device enclosure.
segment.target: Depending on the device, sometimes the controller is attached to the physical battery and sometimes it's attached to the device enclosure.

segment.source: Thus, it's possible to create a battery object even when no batteries are present.
segment.target: Thus, it's possible to create a battery object even when no batteries are present.

segment.source: Other times, the battery object may be null.
segment.target: Other times, the battery object may be null.

segment.source: Once you have an aggregate battery object, call GetReport to get the corresponding BatteryReport.
segment.target: Once you have an aggregate battery object, call GetReport to get the corresponding BatteryReport.

segment.source: Get individual battery reports
segment.target: Get individual battery reports

segment.source: You can also create a BatteryReport object for individual batteries.
segment.target: You can also create a BatteryReport object for individual batteries.

segment.source: Use GetDeviceSelector with the FindAllAsync method to obtain a collection of DeviceInformation objects that represent any battery controllers that are connected to the device.
segment.target: Use GetDeviceSelector with the FindAllAsync method to obtain a collection of DeviceInformation objects that represent any battery controllers that are connected to the device.

segment.source: Then, using the Id property of the desired DeviceInformation object, create a corresponding Battery with the FromIdAsync method.
segment.target: Then, using the Id property of the desired DeviceInformation object, create a corresponding Battery with the FromIdAsync method.

segment.source: Finally, call GetReport to get the individual battery report.
segment.target: Finally, call GetReport to get the individual battery report.

segment.source: This example shows how to create a battery report for all batteries connected to the device.
segment.target: This example shows how to create a battery report for all batteries connected to the device.

segment.source: Access report details
segment.target: Access report details

segment.source: The BatteryReport object provides a lot of battery information.
segment.target: The BatteryReport object provides a lot of battery information.

segment.source: For more info, see the API reference for its properties: Status (a BatteryStatus enumeration), ChargeRateInMilliwatts, DesignCapacityInMilliwattHours, FullChargeCapacityInMilliwattHours, and RemainingCapacityInMilliwattHours.
segment.target: For more info, see the API reference for its properties: Status (a BatteryStatus enumeration), ChargeRateInMilliwatts, DesignCapacityInMilliwattHours, FullChargeCapacityInMilliwattHours, and RemainingCapacityInMilliwattHours.

segment.source: This example shows some of the battery report properties used by the basic battery app, that's provided later in this topic.
segment.target: This example shows some of the battery report properties used by the basic battery app, that's provided later in this topic.

segment.source: Request report updates
segment.target: Request report updates

segment.source: The Battery object triggers the ReportUpdated event when charge, capacity, or status of the battery changes.
segment.target: The Battery object triggers the ReportUpdated event when charge, capacity, or status of the battery changes.

segment.source: This typically happens immediately for status changes and periodically for all other changes.
segment.target: This typically happens immediately for status changes and periodically for all other changes.

segment.source: This example shows how to register for battery report updates.
segment.target: This example shows how to register for battery report updates.

segment.source: Handle report updates
segment.target: Handle report updates

segment.source: When a battery update occurs, the ReportUpdated event passes the corresponding Battery object to the event handler method.
segment.target: When a battery update occurs, the ReportUpdated event passes the corresponding Battery object to the event handler method.

segment.source: However, this event handler is not called from the UI thread.
segment.target: However, this event handler is not called from the UI thread.

segment.source: You'll need to use the Dispatcher object to invoke any UI changes, as shown in this example.
segment.target: You'll need to use the Dispatcher object to invoke any UI changes, as shown in this example.

segment.source: Example: basic battery app
segment.target: Example: basic battery app

segment.source: Test out these APIs by building the following basic battery app in Microsoft Visual Studio.
segment.target: Test out these APIs by building the following basic battery app in Microsoft Visual Studio.

segment.source: From the Visual Studio start page, click New Project, and then under the Visual C\# Windows Universal templates, create a new app using the Blank App template.
segment.target: From the Visual Studio start page, click New Project, and then under the Visual C\# Windows Universal templates, create a new app using the Blank App template.

segment.source: Next, open the file MainPage.xaml and copy the following XML into this file (replacing its original contents).
segment.target: Next, open the file MainPage.xaml and copy the following XML into this file (replacing its original contents).

segment.source: If your app isn't named App1, you'll need to replace the first part of the class name in the previous snippet with the namespace of your app.
segment.target: If your app isn't named App1, you'll need to replace the first part of the class name in the previous snippet with the namespace of your app.

segment.source: For example, if you created a project named BasicBatteryApp, you'd replace with .
segment.target: For example, if you created a project named BasicBatteryApp, you'd replace with .

segment.source: You should also replace with .
segment.target: You should also replace with .

segment.source: Next, open your project's MainPage.xaml.cs file and replace the existing code with the following.
segment.target: Next, open your project's MainPage.xaml.cs file and replace the existing code with the following.

segment.source: If your app isn't named App1, you'll need to rename the namespace in the previous example with the name you gave your project.
segment.target: If your app isn't named App1, you'll need to rename the namespace in the previous example with the name you gave your project.

segment.source: For example, if you created a project named BasicBatteryApp, you'd replace namespace with namespace .
segment.target: For example, if you created a project named BasicBatteryApp, you'd replace namespace with namespace .

segment.source: Finally, to run this basic battery app: on the Debug menu, click Start Debugging to test the solution.
segment.target: Finally, to run this basic battery app: on the Debug menu, click Start Debugging to test the solution.

segment.source: Tip To receive numeric values from the BatteryReport object, debug your app on the Local Machine or an external Device (such as a Windows Phone).
segment.target: Tip To receive numeric values from the BatteryReport object, debug your app on the Local Machine or an external Device (such as a Windows Phone).

segment.source: When debugging on a device emulator, the BatteryReport object returns null to the capacity and rate properties.
segment.target: When debugging on a device emulator, the BatteryReport object returns null to the capacity and rate properties.
